Fig. 1 (a) Catalytic activities of AC, Fe/AC, Ni/AC, FeNi/AC-500, and physical mixed catalyst (Fe/AC+Ni/AC) in deoxygenation of stearic acid (reaction conditions: 18 mg of stearic acid, 60 mg of prepared samples, temperature of 360 ℃, and reaction time of 1 h); (b) XRD patterns of prepared samples at 2-theta of 10–90°; (c-e) XRD patterns of prepared samples at 2-theta of 40–50°, 50–60°, and 70–80° ranges, respectively; and (f) N2 physisorption isotherms of the prepared samples. Note: Product selectivity uncertainty is ±3 %, Conversion uncertainty is ±2 %. Fig 1 Fig. 2 FT-IR spectra comparisons of stearic acid, prepared samples, and prepared samples treated with stearic acid: (a) Fe/AC, (b) Ni/AC, (c) FeNi/AC-500; and (d) FT-IR spectra comparisons of treated Fe/AC, treated Ni/AC, and treated FeNi/AC-500. Fig 2 Fig. 3 (a) Catalytic performance of FexNiy/AC-500 in deoxygenation of stearic acid; (b) XRD patterns of FexNiy/AC-500 at 2-theta of 10–90°; (c) XRD patterns of FexNiy/AC-500 measured at 2-theta of 40–48°; (d) catalytic performance of Fe1Ni3/AC-T in deoxygenation of stearic acid; (e) XRD patterns of Fe1Ni3/AC-T measured at 2-theta of 10–90°; and (f) XRD patterns of Fe1Ni3/AC-T measured at 2-theta of 40–48° Reaction conditions: 18 mg of stearic acid, 60 mg of prepared catalysts, temperature of 360 ℃, and reaction time of 1 h. Note: Product selectivity uncertainty is ±3 %, Conversion uncertainty is ±2 %. Fig 3 Fig. 4 (a, b) TEM images of Fe1Ni3/AC-900; (c) high-resolution TEM image of Fe1Ni3/AC-900; and (d-f) EDX-mapping images of Fe1Ni3/AC-900. Fig 4 Fig. 5 (a) Fe 2p XPS spectra of Ni/AC, FeNi/AC-500, and Fe1Ni3/AC-900; (b) Ni 2p XPS spectra of Ni/AC, FeNi/AC-500, and Fe1Ni3/AC-900. Fig 5 Fig. 6 The reusability of Fe1Ni3/AC-900 during five consecutive cycles. Note: Product selectivity uncertainty is ±3 %, Conversion uncertainty is ±2 %. Fig 6 Fig. 7 TG-DTG curves at different heating rates (1–20 ℃/min): (a) pure stearic acid, (b) stearic acid and Fe1Ni3/AC-900 catalyst. Fig 7 Fig. 8 Iso-conversional plots of stearic acid without Fe1Ni3/AC-900 at different mass conversion rates: (a) KAS method, (b) FWO method, (c) Starink method; isoconversional plots of stearic acid with Fe1Ni3/AC-900 at different mass conversion rates: (d) KAS method, (e) FWO method, and (f) Starink method. Fig 8 Fig. 9 In-situ DRIFTS characterization of stearic acid deoxygenation on (a) catalyst-free, (b) Fe1Ni3/AC-900 catalyst. Fig 9 Fig. 10 The plausible deoxygenation pathways of stearic acid over Fe1Ni3/AC-900 catalyst. Fig 10 Table 1 Textural properties of the prepared samples. equally to this work. Although FeNi bimetal-based materials have been used for the deoxygenation of different substrates, no applicable and green support has been reported to load FeNi alloy for the deoxygenation of stearic acid. Furthermore, the activation energy of stearic acid deoxygenation on a FeNi-based catalyst is uncharted and the reaction mechanism remains ambiguous. Herein, we integrate FeNi bimetals on activated carbon (AC) as an efficient green catalyst for the deoxygenation of stearic acid into biofuels. The catalytic performance was systematically investigated with respect to Fe/Ni molar ratios and calcination temperatures. FeNi bimetals supported on AC (FeNi/AC-500) exhibited higher catalytic activity than their monometallic counterparts, indicating the importance of synergistic effect and interaction between Fe and Ni for the deoxygenation of stearic acid. Especially, Fe1Ni3/AC-900 calcined at 900 °C demonstrated the highest stearic acid conversion and linear C17 hydrocarbon (viz., heptadecane and 1-heptadecene) selectivity of 99 % and 94 %, respectively, due to the optimal formation of ordered Fe1Ni3 alloy phases and the lowest apparent activation energy of stearic acid pyrolysis. The distinguished performance surpassed that of noble metal and toxic catalysts in literature works. Therefore, a low-cost, green yet effective FeNi-based catalyst with low activation energy has been developed for the deoxygenation of stearic acid into biofuels. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords FeNi alloy Calcination temperature Deoxygenation Stearic acid Biofuels Data availability The authors are unable or have chosen not to specify which data has been used. 1 Introduction With the rapid development of the economy and the increasing intensity of technological competition, the global trend of excessive dependence on fossil fuels has emerged, making the energy crisis an inevitable challenge for countries around the world [1]. Furthermore, the overuse of fossil fuels also generates high CO2 emissions and a large amount of toxic substances, including particulate matter (such as PM2.5), sulfur oxides, and carbon monoxide, which pose significant threats to human health and the environment [2]. Therefore, many governments around the world recognise the extreme urgency to seek green energy to completely replace fossil fuels by 2050 [3]. In this context, renewable and green energy sources from biomass have garnered significant global attention and support, with particular emphasis in China [4]. Biomass energy is the most abundant renewable resource on the earth characterized by its cleanliness, carbon neutrality, and wide applicability [5,6]. As a typical biomass energy resource, biodiesel (fatty acid methyl ester) is produced mainly by transesterification of lipids (triglycerides) and methanol, which can be used directly in existing diesel engines due to the average molecular weight similar to traditional diesel [7,8]. However, compared to traditional diesel, biodiesel suffers from a lower energy density, worse oxidative stability, and poorer cold flow properties due to the existence of oxygen-containing components [9]. Furthermore, the high content of free fatty acids in waste lipids remains a major challenge for biodiesel production [10]. Thus, a deoxygenation treatment should be performed to eliminate the fuel quality problems of biodiesel, as well as the adverse effects of fatty acid. Developing efficient deoxygenation catalysts is of prime importance in the removal of oxygen-containing groups from fatty acids [11,12]. In recent years, noble metal catalysts, such as Pd [13], Pt [14], and Ru [15] have been widely used as active sites for the deoxygenation of fatty acids into renewable fuel, as well as other value-added hydrocarbons. For example, recently, our group has successfully deoxygenated stearic acid into olefins of C11 C17 in Pt/CeO2 catalyst synthesized with Ce-benzene-1,3,5-tricarboxylic acid (Ce-BTC) metal-organic framework as a precursor [16]. However, the high cost and poor stability of noble metals limit large-scale industrial applications [17]. Remarkably, inexpensive nickel (Ni)-based catalysts exhibit deoxygenation performances comparable to those of noble metals, and have been widely used as significant substitutes for noble metals in recent research efforts [18-20]. For example, our group had recently synthesized NiZn-based catalyst using waste carbon as the carrier, which has successfully deoxygenated stearic acid into C8 C17 olefins [21]. Meanwhile, Tian et al. encapsulated highly dispersed Ni nanoparticles in hierarchical ZSM-5 (Ni@HZ) to improve commercial fatty acids and obtained a high rate of deoxygenation of stearic acid due to the synergism of Ni species and zeolite [19,22]. Likewise, our group recently synthesized Ni/bio-ZSM-5 catalyst with rice husk as a biotemplate to deoxygenate fatty acid into aromatics [6]. Meanwhile, our group has also previously supported Ni particles/clusters on biomass-derived carbon (bio-AC) to efficiently catalyse the pyrolysis of fatty acids and oils into liquid biofuels [23]. The high catalytic activity of Ni/bio-AC was demonstrated to be primarily due to the synergistic effect of active sites for decarboxylation and hydrodeoxygenation, namely abundant oxygen-containing groups (e.g., COH) and Ni nanoparticles for decarboxylation and oxygen-ligated Ni clusters for hydrodeoxygenation [23]. Unfortunately, the monometallic Ni catalyst still suffers from some drawbacks in the deoxygenation process, such as the agglomeration of Ni particles due to excess surface energy, etc. [24,25]. To overcome the above problems, it is necessary to disperse active sites on porous supports (e.g., activated carbon or AC, SiO2, Al2O3) with high surface area, and dope another metal species into parent metal nanoparticles to improve stability and catalytic activity, especially the obvious improvement effect of Fe-doping [24,26]. The existence of Fe species can promote carboxylic group adsorption and prevent CC bond cracking of target hydrocarbon products [25,27]. Based on the benefits of FeNi-based catalysts, the formation of a bimetallic Fe-Ni alloy has been proven to be conducive to the deoxygenation of fatty acids or other substrates [28,29]. For example, Han et al. [30], Zulkepli et al. [31], and Hsu et al. [32], have developed FeNi/SiO2 on the deoxygenation or hydrodeoxygenation of lauric acid, triolein, and p-cresol, respectively, with substrate conversion of 85 %, 96.1 %, and 100 %. In another work, Cheng et al. [33] used FeNi/Al2O3 to hydrodeoxygenate methyl laurate into C12 alkane. Furthermore, FeNi-based catalysts have also been used to deoxygenate or hydrodeoxygenate syringol [34], and more importantly, bio-oil [35] and palm oil [36]. Meanwhile, Khalit et al. [37] have used FeNi/AC to deoxygenate cooking oil waste (consisting of 2.1 % by weight of stearic acid) into linear C17 biofuel (heptadecane + heptadecene), with a selectivity of 18 %. The AC support was used to prevent coking and ensure the high long-term stability of the catalyst. Based on this, Zhong et al. [25] acknowledged the potential of FeNi supported on carbon-based material for the deoxygenation of stearic acid into linear C17. Therefore, they loaded FeNi on cyanide-calcined graphitic carbon, and it was found that 100 % stearic acid conversion, with linear C17 selectivity of 72.5 % can be achieved. Despite the excellent results, cyanide is highly toxic [38], which inhibits its potential to be commercialized as a safe and environmentally friendly catalyst in the future. Therefore, an excellent yet environmentally friendly or greener support is needed to be rationally designed for FeNi loading, which is one of the research gaps. Furthermore, despite the potential of FeNi-based catalysts to deoxygenate stearic acid into biofuels such as linear C17, to the knowledge of the authors, no work has been done to study the activation energy for deoxygenation of stearic acid into linear C17 on different catalysts, including FeNi-based catalyst. Hence, this is another research gap that needs to be addressed. Inspired by these works and research gaps, herein a series of FeNi supported on AC catalysts, which is more environmentally friendly or greener than cyanide, were prepared by the isovolume impregnation method for the deoxygenation of stearic acid via catalytic pyrolysis. To maximize the potential of FeNi supported on AC in deoxygenating stearic acid, we effectively regulated the crystal structures of Fe-Ni alloy by changes in Fe/Ni molar ratio and calcination temperature. Various characterization methods, including transmission electron microscopy (TEM), X-ray diffraction (XRD), Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectra, and inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES), were used to confirm the morphology, crystal structure, and composition of prepared catalysts. To study the activation energy (Eα ) of stearic acid deoxygenation in FeNi/AC, thermogravimetric derivative thermogravimetric curves (TG-DTG) were used. It was then fitted to the Kissinger Akahira Sunose (KAS) [39,40], Flynn Wall Ozawa (FWO) [39,40], and Starink [41] methods. Moreover, the deoxygenation process of stearic acid over prepared catalysts was analyzed by in-situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS), and the corresponding deoxygenation pathway of stearic acid was also clearly proposed. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Chemicals Nickel nitrate hexahydrate (Ni(NO3)2·6H2O, 99 %), ferric nitrate nonahydrate (Fe(NO3)3·9H2O, 98 %), ethyl acetate (C4H8O2, 99.5 %), ethanol (CH3CH2OH, 99.5 %), and granular activated carbon (AC, analytical grade) were purchased from China National Medicines Corporation Ltd. Stearic acid (C18H36O2, 98 %), heptadecane (C17H36, 99 %), and 1-heptadecene (C17H34, 99.5 %) were purchased from Shanghai Aladdin Bio-Chem Technology Co., Ltd. All reagents were used without any pretreatments. 2.2 Synthesis of Fe/AC, Ni/AC, and FexNiy/AC-T catalysts Fe/AC, Ni/AC, and FexNiy/AC-T (Fe/Ni molar ratio (x/y), and calcination temperature (T)) catalysts were prepared by the isovolume impregnation method. For the preparation of the Fe/AC catalyst, 404.0 mg of Fe(NO3)3·9H2O was dissolved in a certain amount of deionized water, and the mixture was stirred at room temperature for 1 h. Then, 223.4 mg of AC was added into the above aqueous solution and dried at 110 ℃ overnight. The dried solid was calcined at 500 ℃ in Ar atmosphere for 5 h (with a heating rate of 2 ℃/min) and then reduced at 500 ℃ in 5 %H2/Ar atmosphere for 2 h (with a heating rate of 2 ℃/min) to obtain Fe/AC catalyst. Ni/AC catalyst was prepared by the same procedure above, and the only difference is that the amount of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O and AC was 291.0 mg and 234.8 mg, respectively. Similarly, different FexNiy/AC-T catalysts were synthesized by strictly regulating the ratio of Fe(NO3)3·9H2O and Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (x/y from 1:3 to 3:1), and calcination temperature (T is 500, 700, and 900 ℃, respectively). Besides, the Fe/AC+Ni/AC sample was synthesized by physically mixing the same amount of powdery Fe/AC and Ni/AC in a mortar. 2.3 Characterization methods The crystalline structure identification was analyzed by X-ray diffraction (XRD, Rigaku Ultima IV) operating at 15 mA and 40 kV with a Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54 Å) and step size of 0.02°. The textural properties (surface area, average pore diameter, and total pore volume) of prepared samples were determined by N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms (Micromeritics ASAP 2460) at 77 K. The morphological structures were investigated by transmission electron microscopy (TEM, Philips, TECNAI F30) equipped with an energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX). The metal contents were measured by inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES, Agilent, 5100 SVDV). The FTIR spectra of prepared samples were obtained by a Nicolet 6700 FTIR spectrometer in the frequency range of 4000–400 cm−1. Additionally, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Thermo Scientific K-Alpha+) was used to analyze the surface chemistry, and the data were calibrated by C1s with the binding energy (B.E.) of 284.8 eV. 2.4 Catalytic performance evaluation method In a typical experiment procedure, 60 mg of stearic acid and 18 mg of catalyst were loaded into a microreactor (volume of 2 mL). Thereafter, the microreactor was heated to the targeted reaction temperature, and maintained for a period of time. After the reaction, the product was analyzed by gas chromatography (GC, Agilent 7890A) equipped with a flame ion detector (FID) and KB-FFAP column (60 m × 0.32 mm×0.25 μm). Quantitative analysis was performed using external calibration curves for each compound. The conversion of stearic acid and the selectivity of the product was calculated using the following equations. (1) C o n v e r s i o n ( % ) = [ C 17 H 35 COOH ] initial − [ C 17 H 35 COOH ] final [ C 17 H 35 COOH ] initial × 100 % (2) S e l e c t i v i t y ( % ) = [ C i ] product ∑ i = 1 n [ C i ] product × 100 % Where [C17H35COOH]initial and [C17H35COOH]final represent the stearic acid concentration before reaction and stearic acid concentration after reaction, respectively; [Ci ]product means the concentration of product i. The apparent activation energy (Eα ) without and with FexNiy/AC-T catalyst was calculated to analyze the difficulty level of stearic acid pyrolysis through the different isoconversional methods. The corresponding experiments were performed on the thermogravimetric analyzer (TGA, TG-209F3), and the testing conditions were as follows: N2 flow rate of 30 mL/min, temperature range from room temperature to 1073 K (800 ℃), and heating rate of 1, 2.5, 5, 10, and 20 K/min, respectively. The isoconversional methods of Kissinger Akahira Sunose (KAS) [39,40], Flynn Wall Ozawa (FWO) [39,40], and Starink [41], described as Eqs. (3)–(5), respectively, were employed to calculate the Eα . (3) ln ( β T 2 ) = ln ( A E a R g ( α ) ) − E α R T (4) ln ( β ) = ln ( A E a R g ( α ) ) − 1.052 E α R T − 5.331 (5) ln ( β T 1.92 ) = − 1.0008 E α R T + Constant Wherein, β is the heating rate (K/min), T is the temperature (K), A is the apparent pre-exponential factor, R is the gas constant (8.314 J/(mol·K)), α is the mass conversion, which reflects progress degree of the thermal degradation, and g(α) represents the integral function of conversion. In addition, the apparent reaction order (n) was calculated by the extended Avrami theory [42], as described in Eq. (6). (6) ln ( − ln ( 1 − α ) ) = ln ( A ) − E α R T − n ln β 2.5 In-situ drifts study In-situ DRIFTS was performed on Thermo Scientific Nicolet iS50 spectrometer equipped with a KBr optical beam and a Mercury-Cadmium-Telluride (MCT) detector scanning in the wavenumber range of 4000–600 cm−1 to study the changes of the functional group during deoxygenation process of stearic acid, and revealed corresponding reaction pathways. Firstly, the mixture of catalyst and stearic acid was ground evenly and placed into an infrared cell equipped with a Zn-Se window. Then, the N2 stream with a flow rate of 20 mL/min passed through the infrared cell for 20 min at 50 ℃, and obtained the background spectrum. Finally, the temperature was rapidly raised to 360 ℃, and subsequently maintained for 15 min under 20 mL/min of N2 stream. 3 Result and discussion 3.1 Catalytic activities and characterizations of Fe/AC, Ni/AC, and FeNi/AC-500 The catalytic activities of prepared samples in deoxygenation of stearic acid are exhibited in Fig. 1a , including AC, Fe/AC, Ni/AC, FeNi/AC-500 (Fe/Ni molar ratio of 1:1), and physically mixed catalyst (Fe/AC+Ni/AC). It can be found that nearly 83 % of high heptadecane (C17) selectivity was obtained over AC, whereas the stearic acid conversion was only 31 %. It was believed that the surface oxygen groups in AC would be one of the active sites [23]. When Fe or Ni was loaded on AC, the stearic acid conversion was improved significantly, namely 63 % for Fe/AC and 85 % for Ni/AC. However, excluding the C17 selectivity (Fe/AC: 71 % vs. Ni/AC: 73 %), the distribution of other products varied significantly between catalysts, where Fe/AC predominantly produced 1-octadecanol (10 %), 1-heptadecene (C17 =, 9.6 %), and C8 C16 (9.4 %), while Ni/AC obtained C17 = (19.2 %), C8 C16 (5.6 %), and octadecane (C18, 2.2 %). Interestingly, FeNi/AC-500 exhibited better performance in stearic acid conversion (88 %) and C17 linear hydrocarbons selectivity (C17 + C17 =, 97 %) when compared to Fe/AC or Ni/AC. Additionally, FeNi/AC-500 effectively suppressed CC bond cracking, as evidenced by the absence of short-chain products such as C8 C16. This enhancement is likely due to the synergistic interaction between Fe and Ni. Moreover, compared to FeNi/AC-500, physically mixed Fe/AC+Ni/AC (with weak interaction between Fe and Ni active sites) possessed relatively lower stearic acid conversion (78 %) and C17 linear hydrocarbons selectivity (82 %), which indicated the intimate interaction of Fe and Ni active sites would be critical to the catalytic performance. Fig. 1b shows the XRD patterns of Fe/AC, Ni/AC, and FeNi/AC-500 catalysts. The wide diffraction peak at 23.8° can be attributed to the presence of amorphous AC [43]. For Ni/AC, three characteristic peaks at 44.6°, 51.9°, and 76.5° were observed, which were associated with the (111), (200), and (220) crystal faces of the face-centered cubic (fcc) Ni (JCPDF#04–0850), respectively [44]. The cubic Fe3O4 structure was found in Fe/AC from the characteristic peaks at 2-theta of 30.2° (220), 35.5° (311), 37.3° (222), 43.3° (400), 53.6° (422), 57.2° (511), 62.8° (440), and 74.4° (533) [45], suggesting Fe species were not reduced completely. Additionally, the characteristic peaks of metallic Ni and Fe3O4 appeared in FeNi/AC-500, demonstrating the successful loading of Ni and Fe on AC. Meanwhile, as shown in Fig. 1c-e, three main diffraction peaks (44.2°, 51.6°, and 76.2°) of metallic Ni in FeNi/AC-500 slightly shifted toward lower 2-theta compared to Ni/AC, indicating that some Fe successfully migrated into the Ni matrix to form the alloy structure in FeNi/AC-500 [24,46] due to their distinct atomic radius (Ni: 1.24 Å, Fe: 1.26 Å) [47]. It was reported that the formation of Fe-Ni alloy was conducive to the deoxygenation of fatty acids [25], therefore the catalytic activity of FeNi/AC-500 was more substantial than that of physically mixed Fe/AC+Ni/AC in the deoxygenation of stearic acid. N2 physisorption isotherms in Fig. 1f show that AC, Fe/AC, Ni/AC, and FeNi/AC-500 all exhibited typical IV isotherms with a noticeable H3 type hysteresis loop over P/P0 value of 0.50 to 0.99, suggesting the existence of mesoporous structure [48]. The corresponding textural properties are given in Table 1 . It can be found that the BET surface area (S BET) of Fe/AC was lower than that of AC, while Ni/AC was slightly higher than AC, which may be attributed to the different interactions between metal (Fe or Ni) and support (AC). In addition, FeNi/AC-500 has an S BET value between those of Fe/AC and Ni/AC, probably due to the overlapping of Fe and Ni metals supported onto the AC [24]. Furthermore, the pore volume (V p) increased after the immobilization of metals on AC, while the average pore diameter (d p) showed little difference among AC, Fe/AC, Ni/AC, and FeNi/AC-500. It should be noted that the adsorption and activation of stearic acid over the catalyst significantly affected the catalytic performance, with carboxylate intermediates serving as crucial evidence of such interactions [49]. Fig. 2 compares the FTIR spectra of pure stearic acid, prepared samples (Fe/AC, Ni/AC, and FeNi/AC-500), and prepared samples treated with stearic acid (treated Fe/AC, treated Ni/AC, and treated FeNi/AC). For pure stearic acid, the IR band at 2925 cm−1 corresponded to the asymmetric stretching vibration of -CH3, and characteristic peaks at 2845 and 1470 cm−1 were attributed to the stretching vibration and bending vibration of -CH2-, respectively [23]. Furthermore, the vibration of C=O attributed to -COOH was around 1703 cm−1 [50]. It can be seen from Fig. 2a-c that characteristic IR bands at 2925 and 2845 cm−1 can be also observed over stearic acid-treated samples, suggesting the successful adsorption of stearic acid on the surface of the above samples. Meanwhile, the IR band corresponding to -COOH was absent, while a new IR band associated with carboxylate (-COO−, 1565 cm−1) appeared over all treated samples [51], which indicated the chemisorption of stearic acid on prepared samples. Besides, detailed FTIR spectra comparisons of treated samples are depicted in Fig. 2d. Compared to Fe/AC, Ni/AC presented more obvious IR band of -COO−, which demonstrated the higher activation ability for stearic acid, therefore exhibiting higher stearic acid conversion (Ni/AC: 85 % vs. Fe/AC: 63 %). Additionally, owing to the synergistic effect of Fe and Ni, FeNi/AC-500 possessed the highest intensity of -COO− adsorption peak in comparison with monometallic Fe/AC and Ni/AC, which was consistent with the most excellent catalytic performance in terms of stearic acid conversion (88 %) over FeNi/AC-500. 3.2 Catalytic activities and characterizations of FEXNIY/AC-T Subsequently, the effects of Fe/Ni molar ratio (x:y is from 3:1 to 1:3) and calcination temperature (T is 500, 700, or 900 ℃) on catalytic performance and crystal structure of FexNiy/AC-T were explored, and the corresponding results are shown in Fig. 3 . It can be seen from Fig. 3a that as the Fe/Ni molar ratio decreased from 3:1 to 1:3 with the stearic acid conversion increasing from 86 % to 94 %, and the selectivity of C17 linear hydrocarbons exhibited variation trend of volcanic type, wherein, 94 % of conversion and 91 % of C17 linear hydrocarbons selectivity over Fe1Ni3/AC-500 was considered as the best catalytic performance. The XRD patterns displayed in Fig. 3b and c suggested that the Fe/Ni molar ratio significantly affected the crystal structure of prepared samples, especially the different shifts of Ni species (at 44.6° diffraction peak). For instance, Fe1Ni3/AC-500 shifted most obviously towards lower 2-theta among all prepared samples, indicating that the maximum amount of Fe-Ni alloy structure formed in Fe1Ni3/AC-500. Therefore, this catalyst showed the most excellent catalytic performance. In addition, the ICP-OES results given in Table S1 also suggested the actual content of Fe and Ni exhibited the same trend as the Fe/Ni molar ratio, being consistent with XRD diffraction peak variation of Fe and Ni species. Moreover, Fig. 3d shows the catalytic performance comparison of Fe1Ni3/AC-T prepared at different calcination temperatures, and the results demonstrated that with the increase of calcination temperature (500–900 ℃), both stearic acid conversion and C17 linear hydrocarbons selectivity presented the upward tendency. The highest conversion rate of 99 % and the highest selectivity of 94 % for C17 linear hydrocarbons were achieved with Fe1Ni3/AC-900, which was mainly due to the transformation in crystal structure at different calcination temperatures. It can be verified by Fig. 3e and f that the crystal structure of Fe1Ni3/AC-T transformed from Fe0.64Ni0.36 to a more orderly FeNi3 alloy as the calcination temperature increased, which improved the oxidation resistance of the catalyst to retain more amount of metallic nickel (Ni0), and thus enhanced catalytic performance in deoxygenation of stearic acid [30]. The representative TEM images of Fe1Ni3/AC-900 are shown in Fig. 4 . It can be seen from Fig. 4a and b that FeNi3 alloy particles were in the size range of 50–100 nm, and well dispersed on AC support. Particularly, the (111) crystal plane of FeNi3 with a lattice spacing of 0.210 nm (JCPDS#65–3244) is shown in Fig. 4c, which was in agreement with the XRD results. Besides, EDX-mapping images (Fig. 4d-f) demonstrate that Fe and Ni elements were uniformly dispersed throughout the nanoparticles, and loaded on the AC support as active sites for deoxygenation of stearic acid. Furthermore, the N2 physisorption isotherms and corresponding textural properties of Fe1Ni3/AC-900 are also shown in Fig. 1f and Table 1, demonstrating the lower SBET (649.8 m2/g) and higher average pore diameter (3.6 nm) compared to the bare AC support. In the deoxygenation process of stearic acid, the metal valence state plays a vital role in determining the catalytic performance [30]. Herein, XPS characterization was used to analyze the chemical valence states of Fe and Ni species on Ni/AC, FeNi/AC-500, and Fe1Ni3/AC-900. First, Fe 2p XPS spectra in Fig. 5a show an overlap of oxidated Fe (Fe2+ and Fe3+) with the satellite peak of Fe2+ in the binding energy range between 707 and 716 eV [24], and the existence of oxidated Fe is beneficial to the adsorption of stearic acid on the catalyst surface. Additionally, the characteristic peak of metallic Fe (Fe0) was observed at 706.0 eV on Fe1Ni3/AC-900, while it was visibly absent in FeNi/AC-500, which further confirmed the existence of FeNi3 alloy. As can be seen in Ni 2p XPS spectra (Fig. 5b), all prepared samples had the characteristic peak around 852.3–853.1 eV, which was associated with metallic Ni (Ni0). Besides, the main peak at 855.3–856.2 eV with the satellite peak over 861.0–861.8 eV indicated the existence of oxidized Ni species (Ni2+) [52]. Interestingly, the characteristic peaks of Ni in Fe1Ni3/AC-900 shifted towards lower binding energy when compared to Ni/AC and FeNi/AC-500, suggesting that more electron was transferred to Ni species to promote the formation of Ni0. Accordingly, the Ni0/Ni2+ ratios were 0.14, 0.20, and 0.33 on Ni/AC, FeNi/AC-500, and Fe1Ni3/AC-900, respectively, which was conducive to the deoxygenation of stearic acid. Based on the above results of FTIR, XRD, TEM, and XPS characterizations, it can be concluded that the excellent catalytic performance of Fe1Ni3/AC-900 in deoxygenation of stearic acid was attributed to the following three aspects: (i) the formation of Fe1Ni3 alloy prevented the oxidation of Ni0, ensuring sufficient and stable active sites for deoxygenation; (ii) the existence of Fe species promoted the adsorption of the carboxylic group (substrates); and (iii) the interaction of Fe and Ni facilitated the desorption of long-chain hydrocarbons, therefore inhibiting the short chain products and improving the C17 linear hydrocarbons selectivity. 3.3 Reusability of Fe1Ni3/AC-900 catalyst The reusability of Fe1Ni3/AC-900 catalyst was also investigated, in which the initial reaction conditions were 8 mg of stearic acid, 60 mg of prepared catalysts, temperature of 360 ℃, and reaction time of 1 h. After the reaction, the Fe1Ni3/AC-900 was separated from the product, washed three times with a mixture of ethanol and deionized water, dried at 80 ℃ overnight, and then reused for the next batch reaction of deoxidation of stearic acid. As shown in Fig. 6 , although the stearic acid conversion decreased from 99 % to 64 % when Fe1Ni3/AC-900 was used 5 times, the C17 product selectivity was kept essentially constant, which implied the active sites of Fe1Ni3/AC-900 were not deactivated during deoxidation of stearic acid. It should be noted that the decrease in the conversion of stearic acid may be due to the experimental weight loss of Fe1Ni3/AC-900 during the recycling process. 3.4 Apparent kinetic of stearic acid pyrolysis Moreover, TG-DTG curves of stearic acid without and with Fe1Ni3/AC-900 catalyst at different heating rates are presented in Fig. 7 , whereby Ti, Tf , and Tm represent initial pyrolysis temperature, final pyrolysis temperature, and maximum weight loss temperature, respectively. As can be seen in Fig. 7a, Ti, Tf , and Tm showed an increasing trend with the increase of the heating rate due to the thermal hysteresis effect, and therefore the TG and DTG curves moved to a higher temperature range [41]. The DTG curves of stearic acid without Fe1Ni3/AC-900 at different heating rates all showed only one distinct peak, indicating the one-stage pyrolysis of stearic acid without Fe1Ni3/AC-900 [53]. It should be noted that DTG curves (Fig. 7b) have two distinct peaks after the addition of Fe1Ni3/AC-900, which suggests two-stage pyrolysis of stearic acid. In addition, the TG analysis of Fe1Ni3/AC-900 in Fig. S1 exhibits the major weight loss that occurred after 600 ℃, demonstrating the weight loss was all due to the pyrolysis of stearic acid in Fig. 7b. Herein, three different methods of KAS, FWO, and Starink were used to fit and calculate the apparent kinetic parameters at different mass conversion rates (α), and the results are given in Fig. 8 , Table S2, and Table S3. It can be seen from Table S2 that the apparent activation energy (Eα ) of stearic acid pyrolysis without Fe1Ni3/AC-900 did not present significant change at different mass conversion rates, which was consistent with one-stage pyrolysis result of DTG. The corresponding average Eα were 78.4 (KAS), 82.8 (FWO), and 74.7 kJ/mol (Starink), respectively, and the good linear relationship (all R 2 were greater than 0.98) verified the reliability. In addition, the apparent reaction order (n) was calculated as 1.52 (Fig. S2 and Table S4) based on extended Avrami theory, which is in accordance with the 1.5-level reaction model reported in the literature [53]. Different from the results above, as given in Table S3, there was an obvious difference in Eα values before and after 50 % of α for stearic acid pyrolysis with Fe1Ni3/AC-900, being following the two-stage pyrolysis of stearic acid in DTG analysis. The 64.0 (KAS), 68.9 (FWO), and 63.1 kJ/mol (Starink) of average Eα values were lower than those of stearic acid pyrolysis without Fe1Ni3/AC-900, further demonstrating the high efficiency of Fe1Ni3/AC-900 in enhancing stearic acid pyrolysis. 3.5 The plausible reaction mechanism Furthermore, in-situ DRIFTS was used to study the adsorption and conversion behaviors of stearic acid over Fe1Ni3/AC-900. As shown in Fig. 9a , for catalyst-free, the characteristic bands appearing around 2920 and 2849 cm−1 were associated with stretching vibrations of -CH3 (v -CH3) and -CH2- (v -CH2-), respectively [23]. The IR band belonging to C=O of stearic acid (v C=O) was observed around 1750 cm−1 [53]. Besides, the IR of gas-phase CO2 was found around 2360 cm−1 [54], suggesting stearic acid underwent a certain degree of decarboxylation to produce long-chain hydrocarbons at 360 ℃ even without a catalyst. However, the variation rate of the abovementioned characteristic IR bands was much slower than those when Fe1Ni3/AC-900 was employed (Fig. 9b), which demonstrated catalyst was of vital importance in the decarboxylation of stearic acid. As can be seen in Fig. 9b, the IR band of v C=O (1765 cm−1) exhibited a redshift over Fe1Ni3/AC-900 when compared to that of the catalyst-free sample, which indicated stearic acid was well-adsorbed on Fe1Ni3/AC-900. The enhanced intensity of v -CH3, v -CH2-, δ -CH3 and gas-phase CO2 bands demonstrated stearic acid can be converted to long-chain hydrocarbons (e.g. C17) by decarboxylation reaction. Surprisingly, a sharp -OH band (3560 cm−1) associated with free water and a broad -OH band (3200–3400 cm−1) corresponding to fatty alcohol were also observed over Fe1Ni3/AC-900, indicating in-situ dehydrogenation of stearic acid or vapor phase reforming process occurred with the introduction of Fe1Ni3/AC-900, and the obtained active hydrogen species can promote the conversion of stearic acid to octadecanol intermediates via hydrodehydration [23,55]. Therefore, both decarboxylation and hydrodeoxygenation pathways existed in the deoxygenation process of stearic acid over Fe1Ni3/AC-900. In addition, the IR band around 1620 cm−1 was attributed to stretching vibrations of C=C (v C=C), confirming the formation of long-chain olefin products (e.g. C17 =) [21]. Consequently, the plausible deoxygenation pathways of stearic acid over Fe1Ni3/AC-900 are shown in Fig. 10 . It can be seen that the production of C17 hydrocarbon began with the adsorption of stearic acid (C17H35COOH) onto Fe1Ni3/AC-900 catalyst (reaction I). It is then divided into two possible pathways. The first pathway involves the decarboxylation of adsorbed stearic acid (reaction II) into C17 by releasing CO2. Finally, the C17 is desorbed from the surface of the catalyst (reaction III). Meanwhile, the second pathway involves the in-situ dehydrogenation of adsorbed stearic acid into carboxylate (reaction IV) by releasing H*. The carboxylate then undergoes hydrodehydration (reaction V) by reacting with H2 to form 1-octadecanol and H2O. Next, 1-octadecanol undergoes decarbonylation and dehydration (reaction VI) to form C17 by releasing CO and H2. Finally, the C17 is desorbed from the surface of catalyst (reaction III). In addition, the production of C17 = hydrocarbons also begin with stearic acid (C17H35COOH) onto Fe1Ni3/AC-900 catalyst (reaction I), followed by in-situ dehydrogenation of adsorbed stearic acid into carboxylate (reaction IV) by releasing H*. The carboxylate is then decarbonylated (reaction VII) to form C17H35O*, which is then hydrogenated into 1-heptadecanol by reacting with H* (reaction VIII). The 1-heptadecanol is then dehydrated (reaction IX) in C17 =, before desorption from the surface of the catalyst (reaction X). It should be noted that, unlike most deoxygenation reactions, which require an external H2 source [56], no external H2 was used in our current study. However, based on the mechanism in Fig. 10, H2 plays an important role in the hydrodehydration of carboxylate in reaction V, which is an intermediate product for the eventual production of C17. As shown in Fig. 10, H2 can be formed upon vapour phase reforming, which involves the reaction between CO and H2O to produce CO2 and H2. The source of CO comes from reactions VII and VI, while H2O comes from reactions IX and V. Meanwhile, H2 can also be obtained from reaction VI. Therefore, even without an external H2 source, H2 can be produced in-situ for the hydrodehydration of carboxylate in these reactions’ steps. 3.6 Comparisons of performance Table 2 shows the comparisons of performance with other catalysts on the deoxygenation of stearic acid. As shown in Table 2, in terms of linear C17 selectivity, Fe1Ni3/AC-900 demonstrated relatively much better performance (94 %) than that of expensive noble metal based catalyst such as Pd/Sibunit Carbon (40 %), Pd/SBA-15 (89 %), Pd/Carbon (30 %) and Ru/Carbon (<60 %), as well as non-noble metal-based catalyst such as Co/Activated carbon (66 %), CuCo/Carbon nanotube (88 %) and NiMo/Greigite (20 %). In terms of stearic acid conversion, Fe1Ni3/AC-900 demonstrated relatively much better performance (99 %) than other catalysts that were used to deoxygenate stearic acid without external H2 such as Pd/Al2O3 (20 %), Ru/Carbon (75 %) and Ni/Bio activated carbon (70 %). Meanwhile, the overall catalytic performance of Fe1Ni3/AC-900 was also better than other reported FeNi-based catalysts such as FeNi/Cyanide, which is toxic. Specifically, the linear C17 selectivity and stearic acid conversion of Fe1Ni3/AC-900 was 94 % and 99 %, respectively, while for FeNi/graphitic carbon from cyanide, the linear C17 selectivity and stearic acid conversion were reported to be 72.5 % and 100 %, respectively. Therefore, by comparison, we have developed an excellent non-noble metal-based catalyst, which is not only cheaper than other noble metals, but also more environmentally friendly than other FeNi-based catalyst for the deoxygenation of stearic acid. 4 Conclusions In conclusion, a series of activated carbon loaded with Fe-Ni bimetallic alloy catalysts were prepared, fully characterized, and used for the catalytic deoxygenation of stearic acid. It was found that the formation of the Fe-Ni alloy demonstrated better adsorption of the fatty acid and activation ability for stearic acid than those of its monometallic counterpart catalysts. The catalytic performance can be further enhanced by tuning the Fe/Ni ratio and calcination temperature. At a Fe/Ni ratio of 1:3 and a calcination temperature of 900 °C (Fe1Ni3/AC-900), a maximum amount of ordered Fe1Ni3 alloy can be formed, which improves the resistance to oxidation of the catalyst to retain more metallic nickel (Ni0). Therefore, Fe1Ni3/AC-900 demonstrated the best catalytic performance with stearic acid conversion of 99 % and linear C17 selectivity of 94 %, demonstrating excellent stearic acid deoxygenation in linear C17 biofuels compared to other reported catalysts. Furthermore, the activation energy of Fe1Ni3/AC-900 based on the KAS, FWO, and Starink methods was determined to be 64.0, 68.9, and 63.1 kJ/mol, respectively, further demonstrating the high efficiency of Fe1Ni3/AC-900 in improving stearic acid pyrolysis. Through the in-situ DRIFTS investigation on Fe1Ni3/AC-900, it was found that C17 can be generated through two possible pathways, either by direct decarboxylation of stearic acid or by a series of dehydrogenation of stearic acid, hydrodehydration of carboxylate and finally decarbonylation and dehydrogenation of 1-octadecanol. Meanwhile, C17 = can be produced through a series of in-situ dehydrogenation of stearic acid, carboxylate decarbonylation, hydrodehydration of C17H35O*, and finally dehydration of 1-heptadecanol. Therefore, a low-cost, environmentally friendly yet effective FeNi-based catalyst with low activation energy has been developed for the deoxygenation of stearic acid into linear C17 biofuels, demonstrating its potential to be further developed and commercialized in the future. coredata.dc:description: Although FeNi bimetal-based materials have been used for the deoxygenation of different substrates, no applicable and green support has been reported to load FeNi alloy for the deoxygenation of stearic acid. Furthermore, the activation energy of stearic acid deoxygenation on a FeNi-based catalyst is uncharted and the reaction mechanism remains ambiguous. Herein, we integrate FeNi bimetals on activated carbon (AC) as an efficient green catalyst for the deoxygenation of stearic acid into biofuels. The catalytic performance was systematically investigated with respect to Fe/Ni molar ratios and calcination temperatures. FeNi bimetals supported on AC (FeNi/AC-500) exhibited higher catalytic activity than their monometallic counterparts, indicating the importance of synergistic effect and interaction between Fe and Ni for the deoxygenation of stearic acid. Especially, Fe1Ni3/AC-900 calcined at 900 °C demonstrated the highest stearic acid conversion and linear C17 hydrocarbon (viz., heptadecane and 1-heptadecene) selectivity of 99 % and 94 %, respectively, due to the optimal formation of ordered Fe1Ni3 alloy phases and the lowest apparent activation energy of stearic acid pyrolysis. The distinguished performance surpassed that of noble metal and toxic catalysts in literature works. Therefore, a low-cost, green yet effective FeNi-based catalyst with low activation energy has been developed for the deoxygenation of stearic acid into biofuels.
